    glioblastomaU8799 ± 8103 ± 598 ± 592 ± 797 ± 598 ± 5
     LN229102 ± 498 ± 5106 ± 491 ± 7106 ± 5100 ± 5
    a

    Independent experiments were run for each polyphenol (n = 5 IV, and n = 5 oral). For the IV administration, each polyphenol was dissolved in DMSO:ethanol (2:1), and the total volume administered was never >30 μL. For the oral administration, each polyphenol was dissolved in a self-microemulsifying drug delivery system comprised of 60% surfactant (emulsifier OP:Cremorphor EL = 1:1), 30% cosurfactant (PEG 400), and 10% oil (ethyl oleate),(123) whereas the total volume administered was never >100 μL. Plasma levels of Resv, Pter, and Quer were measured as previously described.(68, 124) Plasma levels of EGCG were measured as described by Lambert et al.(125) Plasma levels of Curc were measured as described by Zhongfa et al.(126) Plasma levels of Gen were measured as described by Ju et al.(127) After IV administration, peak level of (a) Resv was of 32 ± 4 μM at 5 min, (b) Pter was of 67 ± 7 μM at 5 min, (c) EGCG was of 12 ± 3 μM at 5 min, (d) Curc was of 81 ± 9 μM at 5 min, (e) Quer was of 27 ± 5 μM at 5 min, and (f) Gen was of 35 ± 4 μM at 5 min. Plasma levels of all these PFs were <1 μM at 60 min, excepting for Pter (15 ± 2 μM at 60 min and <1 μM at 120 min). After oral administration, peak level of (a) Resv was of 11 ± 4 μM at 10 min, (b) Pter was of 25 ± 6 μM at 10 min, (c) EGCG was of 5 ± 2 μM at 30 min, (d) Curc was of 27 ± 6 μM at 15 min, (e) Quer was of 8 ± 2 μM at 15 min, and (f) Gen was of 17 ± 5 μM at 10 min. Plasma levels of all these PFs were <1 μM at 60 min. Twenty-four hours after seeding, cancer cells were incubated in the presence of half of the maximum concentration (peak level obtained after IV administration) of each polyphenol. All polyphenols were present for a period of 6 h, at the indicated concentrations, to ensure that the effect also takes into account possible in vivo recycling. After 6 h in the presence of the polyphenols, the culture medium was replaced by fresh medium. The possible effect of polyphenols on cancer cell growth and viability (no. of viable cells) was evaluated 48 h after seeding. Data are expressed as the % of viable cells relative to controls (which were given a 100%). *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01 comparing each value versus its control. Standard deviation of triplicate samples was calculated for three independent samples, mean ± SD (n = 3).

    With this aim, we first measured plasma levels of each polyphenol after their IV (10 mg/kg) or oral (100 mg/kg) administration.
    As shown in Table 2, under in vitro conditions that tend to mimick in vivo bioavailable conditions, only Pter and Curc have some significant effect in a few cancer cell lines (and in these cases, the reduction in the number of viable cells was always less than 20%). These data were not significantly different if polyphenols were added again 48 h after seeding, and the same procedure was repeated (6 h of incubation in the presence of the polyphenols, replacement of the medium, and measurement of the number of viable cells 72 h after seeding). Therefore, we can conclude that, under in vivo conditions, the main underlying mechanism(s) responsible of the anticancer effects elicited by PFs does not necessarily imply a direct interaction between the polyphenol molecule and the cancer cell.
    At this point, it is important to discuss that polyphenols have been also included among compounds that appear as frequent hitters (promiscuous compounds) in many biochemical high throughput screens.(128) In fact, a recent comment(129) states that some of the compounds that should ring the most warning bells are toxoflavin and polyhydroxylated natural phytochemicals such as curcumin, epigallocatechin gallate, genistein, and resveratrol. These, their analogues, and similar natural products persist in being followed up as drug leads and used as “positive” controls even though their promiscuous actions are well documented.(130, 131) In ref 130, it is explained that curcumin interacts with a number of biomolecules through noncovalent and covalent binding. The hydrogen bonding and hydrophobicity of curcumin, arising from the aromatic and tautomeric structures along with the flexibility of the linker group, are responsible for the noncovalent interactions. The α,β-unsaturated β-diketone moiety covalently interacts with protein thiols through Michael reaction. The β-diketo group forms chelates with transition metals, thereby reducing the metal induced toxicity, and some of the metal complexes exhibit improved antioxidant activity as enzyme mimics. Obviously, these chemical features must be carefully taken into account in understanding the mechanisms but do not invalidate the fact that curcumin has antitumor activities in vivo. Regarding ref 131, the authors analyzed five bioactive phenols reported to have medicinal value: capsaicin from chili peppers, curcumin from turmeric, EGCG from green tea, genistein from soybeans, and resveratrol from grapes. They found that each of these widely consumed phytochemicals alters lipid bilayer properties and the function of diverse membrane proteins. Nevertheless, these in vitro experiments must be carefully analyzed. For instance, the phytochemicals double gA induced quencher influx rates at (concentrations in μM) 18.0 ± 0.6 capsaicin, 8.6 ± 1.0 curcumin, 11.2 ± 0.2 EGCG, 26.7 ± 1.4 genistein, and 11.3 ± 0.9 resveratrol. For these effects to have a reliable consequence against cancer under in vivo conditions, bioavailability is essential. However, the rapid in vivo metabolism, as discussed in this Perspective, represents a strong limitation.
    Moreover, it is well-known that polyphenols interfere with the classic cell proliferation MTT colorimetric assay (or other similar assays), giving false readings.(132) These assays are currently used (e.g., by the NIH) in large high throughput screenings. Nevertheless, it is a known fact that is easily overcome by using other methods (i.e., LDH release, trypan blue exclusion, ATP content, sulforhodamine B, flow cytometry, etc.).

    In Vivo Metabolism and Bioavailability Limit Antitumor Efficacy

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A major obstacle in evaluating polyphenols for potential human health benefits is in understanding the bioavailability of these molecules versus their bioefficacy. Problems arise from the use of nonphysiological doses, differences in model species metabolism, and in the traditional progression of only pursuing in vitro successes to in vivo models. Moreover, proposed biological effects of polyphenols must be cautiously considered because (frequently large) differences between studies have been reported. Confounding factors include the type of tumor cell, the in vitro or in vivo conditions, or the concentrations/galenic formulations/nanoparticle associations utilized.
    Dietary polyphenols are rapidly metabolized in tissues and the colonic microbiota.(23, 133, 134) Polyphenols are conjugated with glucuronide, sulfate, and methyl groups (phase II metabolism), and consequently only a very small percentage of free polyphenol is detectable in the blood circulation.(7) Polyphenol metabolites are present in the urine but are also eliminated through biliary secretion and, in part, recycled by the intestinal tract (Figure 2).(135) Nevertheless, in the short term (1st hour), depending on administration (IV or oral), blood levels of aglycones/natural polyphenol structures can vary greatly. Moreover, as deduced from the above statement, further metabolism and recycling mechanisms may keep very low levels for an extended period of time.
    Due to the great number of polyphenols with potential anticancer activities, we focused only on a few examples following clinical trials according to the U.S. NCI.(136)
    An excellent example of the difficulty of bringing polyphenols to clinical successes is resveratrol, which is present in grapes, berries, peanuts, and other plants and has been proposed to exert various health benefits including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antiaging, and anticarcinogenic.(137) As such, resveratrol has been heralded as a dietary supplement that can combat several chronic diseases in humans. Notoriety of resveratrol skyrocketed with the report that it could prevent the three phases of tumor development (initiation, promotion, and progression) in mice.(138) Since that seminal publication, intense interest in the antitumor abilities of resveratrol led to a myriad of reports demonstrating the ability of resveratrol to combat and prevent several human cancers in tissue culture and in mice including breast, prostate, colon, bladder, endometrial, and skin, just to name a few.(137, 139) However, its use in humans as a chemopreventative agent seems to be very limited due to its poor bioavailability.(139, 140) Resveratrol is well tolerated in humans but is readily and rapidly metabolized, leading to a short half-life which hinders its effectiveness.(124, 141) Therefore, understanding the metabolism of resveratrol is vital to its moving forward in the clinic.
    One major metabolic pathway for resveratrol is glucuronidation. Two resveratrol glucuronides have been reported, resveratrol-3-O-glucuronide and resveratrol-4′-O-glucuronide. The UDP-glucuronosyltransferases (UGTs) family of enzymes catalyzes the glucuronidation of resveratrol by conjugating a glucuronic acid moiety to either the 3 or 4′ hydroxyl, thereby altering the biological properties and facilitating its elimination from the body. This fine-tuned regulation (tinged with a bit of irony) uses the same hydroxyl groups that enable the wide range of activity of resveratrol to turn it off and eliminate it. It has been shown that the 3 hydroxyl is by far the preferred position for conjugation and elimination by the UGTs.(142)
    There are 19 functional human UGTs classified into three subfamilies. While orthologues of all these UGT isoforms are found in rats, mice, dogs, and monkeys, tissue distribution and substrate specificity vary widely between species.(143) Thus, it should not be expected that bioavailability of resveratrol in mice or rats will mimic humans. In fact, it is well documented that efforts to show health benefits in humans have been hampered due to its limited bioavailability.(144) There are several ongoing investigative avenues being pursued to overcome resveratrol’s poor bioavailability in humans. Human trials looking at different dosing regiments of resveratrol supplementation, while varying the source and delivery method of resveratrol, have produced some promising results.(145) Other researchers are devising targeted delivery methodologies,(146, 147) while still others have turned to other natural polyphenols with similar antitumor properties.(4)
    Pterostilbene [trans-3,5-dimethoxy-4′-hydroxystilbene], a dimethoxylated resveratrol analogue, is another natural product found in grapes and berries, but this compound is predicted to have a longer half-life and increased bioavailability.(68, 142) The reason for the increased bioavailability is that 2 hydroxyl groups are methoxylated, leaving only the 4′-hydroxyl available for conjugation and elimination. Pterostilbene exhibits equal or significantly more potent activity than resveratrol in several biological assays in mice.(148, 149) Thus, pterostilbene certainly warrants further investigation in humans. The first in humans study showed that pterostilbene was safe and did lower blood pressure,(150, 151) but no large efficacy trial has been reported to date.
    Other polyphenols have met with similar challenges as resveratrol. Genistein is another extensively studied polyphenol, which exhibits poor bioavailability in humans. Several reports have demonstrated the preclinical effectiveness of genistein as an antitumor agent in vitro and in vivo.(152) Genistein exerts its chemotherapeutic effects through altering apoptosis, cell cycle and angiogenesis as well as by inhibiting metastasis. Furthermore, it has been shown effective against different cancers including liver, gastric, lung, colorectal, and breast cancer.(152) Low in vivo bioavailability of genistein is a well-documented hurdle being addressed by altering route of administration or pursuing chemical derivatives. Specifically, daily injection of genistein was found to decrease the incidence of gastric cancers in one mouse model,(51) while the genistein derivative 7-difluoromethyl-5,4′-dimethoxygenistein has been shown effective in animal models of lung cancer.(153) This derivative’s bioefficacy is tied to its increased bioavailability.(153)
    Another pivotal component of assessing bioefficacy is characterization of the mechanism of action and ensuring the target cancer is vulnerable to that strategic attack. In this sense, genistein provides an excellent example with respect to breast cancer. Large epidemiological studies demonstrate a clear association between reduced risk of breast cancer and soy intake. Genistein was quickly identified as the likely polyphenol underlying this reduced risk and several studies showed that genistein did indeed have several cytotoxic and antitumor effects in vitro and in vivo. These effects included induction of apoptosis in both ER-positive and ER-negative cell lines. Excitingly, genistein was found to induce the expression of the breast cancer growth suppressor proteins (BRCA1 and BRCA2) and downstream effector genes.(154) Still contemporary reports show that genistein could stimulate the progression of ER-positive cell lines at low concentrations and that genistein reversed tamoxifen-associated mammary tumor prevention. Nevertheless, this effect was not found in ER-negative tumors.(155, 156) These results make sense considering genistein’s similarity to estrogen structurally. Animal models support these observations and suggest that genistein exposure early in life may reduce risk of breast cancer while genistein exposure may not be safe for postmenopausal women,(152) as genistein can act in an estrogen additive manner under these conditions. Indeed, human clinical trials are underway carefully testing genistein’s antitumor abilities. Lessons here can easily be applied to other polyphenols in the importance of understanding the mechanism of action of the polyphenol and matching that to the appropriate subcancer type.
    Understanding bioavailability of polyphenols, in particular differences that exist between mice and humans, will be key in successfully translating polyphenols to their full potential clinical use. The selection of the appropriate cancer (including the subtype) has been shown to be equally important in translating physiological relevant doses of these polyphenols to enable bioefficacy in humans.

    Toxic/Undesirable Side Effects

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Possible toxicity derived from polyphenol administration could also limit preventive/therapeutic applications and must be also taken into account. Adverse effects of polyphenols have been studied experimentally. Specifically, it is known that some polyphenols, at high concentrations, may have carcinogenic and/or genotoxic effects (e.g., caffeic acid, green tea catechins, or quercetin)(157-159) or may interact with different drugs and affect their biologic effects (for instance the grapefruit juice which increases the bioavailability of drugs such as benzodiazepines and terfenadine).(160) However, all available information concerning the safety of orally administered quercetin, for example, fails to show evidence of in vivo toxicity, including lack of genotoxic/carcinogenic properties.(161) Moreover in the U.S. and Europe, quercetin supplements are commercially available, and clinical trials have been performed that support the beneficial effects of quercetin supplements.(9) Nevertheless, an IV bolus of 1400 mg quercetin/m2 once a week for three weeks, was associated with renal toxicity in two of ten patients (decrease in glomerular flow rate of approximately 20% in the first 24 h).(162) Kidney function did improve within 1 week, and this effect was not observed to be cumulative over subsequent doses in a phase I trial in advanced cancer patients. Thus, a phase II clinical trial using this 1400 mg/m2/week dose was recommended.(163)
    In addition to these observations, there are other examples that clearly indicate that dose, type of administration, and bioavailable concentrations must be set carefully. For example, both animal and epidemiological studies have demonstrated that green tea polyphenols may be (at high doses) hepatotoxic.(164) Obviously special caution must be taken in cases of people having a liver disease. Moreover, green tea polyphenol (0.5–1%)-enriched diets worsen dextran sodium sulfate-induced intestinal inflammation and carcinogenesis.(164) Therefore, the idea that polyphenols (at least a significant number of) can be toxic in large amounts must be seriously taken into account. This possibility was stressed a few years ago by Lambert et al. (2007),(165) who reviewed in vitro and in vivo studies involving many different polyphenols, particularly EGCG and other green tea polyphenols and genistein. Interestingly they also pointed out studies that show apparent pro-oxidant effects of polyphenols.(165) These authors state that despite the lack of reports of toxicity in human volunteers enrolled in clinical studies, liver and kidney function monitoring is required until the risk of toxicity is established in humans.
    In general, polyphenols taken orally are unlikely to be effective unless their actions are not inactivated by conjugation, and/or if the conjugation can be reversed and thus releasing the free polyphenol. In addition, free polyphenols must be available in pharmacologically active concentrations in a form that can be readily utilized by target tissues. However, there is no clear evidence to support conjugation not affecting activity or reversing the conjugations in sufficient quantities elsewhere in the body. The only exception could be if polyphenols come into direct contact with a tumor of the gastrointestinal tract.
    Data from a heavily cited clinical trial supported a safe daily intake for resveratrol at 450 mg/day.(166) Nevertheless, rat studies that received similar equivalent doses of resveratrol orally for 28 days showed a repression of phase I drug metabolizing enzymes and overexpression of other genes such as superoxide dismutase 2, cytochrome P450 reductase, quinone oxidoreductase, or thiosulfate sulfurtransferase.(167) Thus, suggesting potential toxicity. A phase II clinical trial(9) aimed to assess the safety and activity of SRT501 ((E)-5-(4-hydroxystyryl)benzene-1,3-diol, a formulation of resveratrol admistered orally at a dose of 5 g/day for 20 consecutive days), alone or in combination with bortezomib, was canceled after kidney damage (cast nephropathy) was observed in some subjects. However, it is important to note that this resveratrol dose was significantly higher than the concentrations evaluated in safety studies.(7)
    Data from the first clinical trial on pterostilbene(9) have shown that pterostilbene reduced blood pressure in adults using an oral (and safe) dose of 125 mg administered twice per day. Furthermore, the dose of 30 mg IV of pterostilbene/kg per day used in studies from our group was also found safe (because no organ-specific or systemic toxicity was observed in mice).(168)
    The potential of antioxidants (as polyphenols) to neutralize free radicals (and thereby to prevent molecular damages linked to carcinogenesis) led to considering them as anticarcinogens. However, recently published work suggests that antioxidants could make cancer worse. For instance, mice (genetically engineered to increase their susceptibility to melanoma) fed the antioxidant N-acetylcysteine did not develop more skin tumors than controls, but they developed more tumors in the lymph nodes.(169) When N-acetylcysteine or a modified vitamin E was added to human melanoma cells in vitro, it was observed that the antioxidants increased the cells’ mobility and invasion activity of a nearby membrane.(169)N-Acetylcysteine-treated mice showed cancer cells with higher intracellular glutathione (GSH) levels.(169) GSH is the main nonprotein thiols within cells and it is known to promote cancer cell growth and invasiveness.(170, 171) Furthermore, a clinical trial (1994) showed that megadoses of the antioxidant β-carotene (daily given) caused an increase in the risk of lung cancer in male smokers by 18%; whereas two years later, another trial was finished after it was observed that high doses of β-carotene and retinol increased lung cancer risk by 28% in smokers and workers exposed to asbestos. In addition, a recent (2011) trial including more than 35500 men over 50 found that high doses of vitamin E reported a 17% increased risk of prostate cancer.(9) Naturally, it is uncertain to which extent these observations could also apply to polyphenols. However, these are facts that should not be ignored and clear examples of how doses, bioavailability, and the tissue microenvironment may be critical in promotion of one effect or, potentially, the opposite effect.
    Another interesting issue is the relationship between cancer and the microbiota. As recently stressed host’s microbiota may increase, decrease, or have no effect on cancer susceptibility.(172) Microbes and the microbiota may favor carcinogenesis in several ways: (i) changing the ratio of cell proliferation and death in the host, (ii) guiding immune system function, and (iii) influencing metabolism of host-produced factors, ingested foodstuffs, and drugs.(172) Because most polyphenols are metabolized by microbiota and enterocyte enzymes, it is obvious that their oral intake will have variable consequences (depending on the dose and chemical nature) on the microbiota.(173) For instance, polyphenols from green and black tea are potent inhibitors of microorganism growth, apparently more effective against pathogenic bacteria as compared to commensal anaerobes such as Bifidobacterium spp., Clostridium spp., and probiotics such as Lactobacillus spp.(174) However, the regular intake of megadoses of polyphenols will surely diminish our physiological microbiota.
    Taken together, this data suggests that the IV administration of polyphenols will have clear advantages for systemic oncotherapy applications.

    Evidence of in Vivo Reported Antitumor Effects

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Polyphenols manifest their antitumor activities in a variety of ways (see above). These mechanisms of action have been painstakingly worked out for several polyphenols in countless in vitro studies. Because it is clear that the bioavailability of polyphenols is inexorably linked to its bioefficacy, a main goal in this Perspective is to highlight on the antitumor effects of polyphenols that have been demonstrated in vivo (Figure 1). Furthermore, we focus on several reports that have confirmed the mechanism of action in vivo as well (Figure 1).
    Curcumin has been observed to inhibit tumor growth in mouse models of breast cancer(38) and skin cancer.(39) However, only Chun et al. (2003)(39) confirmed that curcumin was indeed blocking proliferation by inhibiting ERK1/2 activation and normalizing NF-kB activation in mouse skin. Chun et al.(39) showed that topically administered curcumin blocks phorbol ester-induced expression of cyclooxygenase-2 in mouse skin through suppression of extracellular signal-regulated kinase activity and NF-kB activation. 12-O-Tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate treatment elicited a robust activation via phosphorylation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK)1/2 and p38 mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinases, both upstream regulators of NF-kB.
    Further, curcumin appears to be an effective antitumor agent in combination with other polyphenols. The association of curcumin and EGCG decreased lung tumor growth in mice(70) and decreased the tumor volume in a mouse model of breast cancer.(71) In both reports, the combination blocked proliferation via induction of cell cycle arrest that was confirmed in both tumor types.(70, 71) Two other reports demonstrate the effective antitumor combination of curcumin with resveratrol. This combination proved effective against head and neck cancer(74) and colon cancer.(75) Unfortunately, neither of these studies confirmed mechanism of action in vivo but did provide in vitro mechanisms consistent with the other in vivo studies discussed here. Specifically, Masuelli et al. (2014)(74) propose cell cycle arrest and increase in apoptosis while Majumdar et al. (2009)(75) propose normalization of NF-kB signaling and inhibition of growth factor signaling.
    Several in vivo studies have been performed examining the antitumor effect of genistein. As a single agent genistein has been shown to decrease tumor growth in hepatocellular cancer in both mice(49) and rats.(50) Both of these studies showed that this polyphenol works through increasing apoptosis as well as inhibiting angiogenesis(49) and proliferation.(50) However, only Chodon and colleagues confirmed their mechanistic data in vivo. Genestein was also shown to work as a single cytotoxic agent against gastric cancers(51) through increased apoptosis and decreased angiogenesis, but this study did not confirm their mechanism in vivo.
    Evidence is also presented that genistein can work effectively in combination with resveratrol in a rat prostate cancer model.(69) This study confirmed inhibition of growth factor signaling as a potential in vivo mechanism of action. Harper et al.(69) showed that genistein and resveratrol (250 mg/kg, oral) reduced prostate tumor growth. Total genistein and resveratrol concentrations in the blood reached 160 and 211 nM, respectively, in rats following a single administration. Polyphenol treatments resulted in a reduction of cellular proliferation and a decrease in insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) protein expression in the prostate. Additionally, genistein activated apoptotic pathways and decreased steroid receptor coactivator-3 in the ventral prostate as a single agent.
    Quercetin also made the list of in vivo antitumor agents but only in combination with other polyphenols. Quercetin with pterostilbene was effective in a murine melanoma model in decreasing tumor growth and preventing metastases, however, the proposed mechanism of action (increased apoptosis) was not validated in vivo.(68) Similarly, the combination of quercetin with EGCG decreased tumor growth in a murine prostate cancer model. The mechanism of action was found in vivo to be increased apoptosis.(7)
    The topical administration quercetin and resveratrol coincorporated in liposomes has been shown effective against inflammatory/oxidative response associated with skin cancer.(175)
    One more polyphenol combination reported (Figure 1) is luteolin with EGCG. This combination decreased lung tumor growth in mice through the unconfirmed proposed mechanism of inhibition of proliferation.(73)
    The polyphenols delphinidin, anthocyanin, and caffeic acid are each represented once as single agents in Figure 1. All three reported to work their antitumor activities via inhibition of NF-kB signaling. Delphindin was shown to decrease tumor growth in a mouse model of prostate cancer and its proposed mechanism was confirmed in vivo.(64) Anthocyanin had demonstrated antitumor activity in a rat esophageal cancer model,(65) and the mechanism was also confirmed in vivo. In contrast, caffeic acid showed anticancer activity in a hepatoma mouse model, but the mechanism was not confirmed.(37)
    Resveratrol clearly has wide reaching antitumor effects and has been shown to the effective as a single agent in rat models of various cancers including, e.g., colon,(25) esophageal,(26) and breast.(27, 28) All four of these reports confirmed the mechanism of action in vivo. Specifically, resveratrol was reported to inhibit proliferation in colon cancer,(25) block inflammation in esophageal cancer,(26) and inhibit NF-κB signaling(27) and increase antioxidant defenses to prevent breast tumor development.(28)
    Singh et al.(28) have shown that resveratrol induces Nrf2-mediated cellular defense pathways resulting in the inhibition of estrogen-induced breast cancer. Co-treatment of rats with resveratrol (given as a 50 mg subcutaneous pellet every month) and 17β-estradiol inhibited estrogen-mediated proliferative changes in mammary tissues resulting in reduced estrogen-induced breast tumor development. This therapeutic combination (or resveratrol alone) significantly upregulated expression of Nrf2 in mammary tissues. Subsequent expression of the Nrf2 responsive antioxidant genes NQO1, SOD3, and OGG1 (which are all involved in protection against oxidative DNA damage) was increased in both resveratrol- and resveratrol + 17β-estradiol-treated mammary tissues. Resveratrol also prevented estrogen induced-inhibition of detoxification genes AOX1 and FMO1. Furthermore, resveratrol was shown to block Nrf2 promoter methylation by estrogen and inhibit expression of the Nrf2 targeting miR-93. Taken together, these results indicate that resveratrol can influence epigenetic regulation of Nrf2 during estrogen-induced breast carcinogenesis.
    Pterostilbene has also been shown to be effective as a single antitumor agent against various cancers. Pterostilbene was confirmed in vivo to block tumor growth through inhibition of NF-κB signaling in a mouse model of skin cancer.(29) Pterostilbene was also confirmed in vivo to induce microRNA-205, resulting in the inhibition of metastasis in a mouse model of breast cancer.(30) However, the frequent use in these in vitro studies of biologically unattainable in vivo concentrations and/or extended treatment periods (24 h or more) seriously questions the relative importance of various proposed mechanisms. For example, prevention of metastases via associated protein 1 in prostate cancer,(176) estrogen receptor α36,(177) or the PI3K/Akt and MAPK signaling pathways in colon cancer(178) or through suppression of the PI-3K/Akt/NF-κB pathway in the case of resveratrol in pancreatic cancer cells.(176) We observed that 20 μM ptrostilbene (a concentration in the upper level of an in vivo achievable intratumoral level, but during a very short time), added to cultured cells for 24 h, only decreased tumor cell viability by approximately 30% in human melanoma, 40% in human lung cancer, 10% human colon cancer, and 25% in human breast cancer.(117) However, cell viability was not significantly altered if the incubation time was <6 h or much longer (96 h) but in the presence of a low Pter concentration (<5 μM; which could be consistent with a recycling mechanism).(117) These results caused us to question reported mechanisms explaining the in vivo induced tumor growth inhibition elicited by pterostilbene (or other related structures), at least under conditions where pterostilbene requires the systemic blood circulation to reach a growing tumor.
    Furthermore, it was shown that topical pterostilbene is able to prevent UV-mediated skin damage in SKH-1 mice and prevent nonmelanoma skin cancer.(31) This last study is the sole example of a topically applied polyphenol, having confirmed in vivo antitumor activity, which works by increasing the natural antioxidant defense mechanisms in the skin.(31)
    Pterostilbene was also recently shown to be effective in the treatment of melanoma.(33) This report is unique for several reasons. Counterintuitively, this treatment does not work in vitro, only in vivo. This represents a potential paradigm shift in how polyphenol antitumor activities are evaluated. Benlloch and colleagues show that pterostilbene works by inhibition of the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production in the brain of a mouse, which weakens the Nrf2-dependent defenses of melanoma and pancreatic cancers. This both inhibits tumor growth and sensitizes the tumor to oxidative stress. Importantly, this only works if the tumor model is under pituitary hormone control. Thus, this anticancer activity could only be observed in vivo. This study suggests a novel approach to be assessed in different tumor models.
    Although there is a number of studies where proposed mechanisms (e.g., inhibition of tumor growth, cell cycle arrest, apoptosis induction, etc.) have in vivo confirmations (see Figure 1), in most cases the full underlying mechanism remains unclear.

    Mechanisms That May Explain Discrepancies between Bioavailability and in Vivo Efficacy

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    From all the above discussion, it is obvious that, although we have clear evidence showing anticancer effects of polyphenols under in vivo conditions, most mechanisms proposed based on in vitro experiments can be (totally or in part) questioned. The fundamental underlying problem is the limited bioavailability.
    The evolving consensus (over the last handful of years) as to how polyphenols mediate potential health benefits in humans has shifted its focus away from any direct antioxidant effect of polyphenols and refocused on polyphenol modulation of cellular signal transduction pathways.(179) Until now, it has been tacitly assumed that the antitumor effects elicited by polyphenols are the consequence of a direct interaction between these molecules and the cancer cell. The work just mentioned above questions,(33) and for the first time, this paradigm. Pterostilbene, by interfering with the physiological (stress-related) adenohypophysis–adrenal axis is capable of inhibiting tumor growth indirectly. The same mechanism was found using curcumin instead of pterostilbene.(33) More importantly, this growth inhibition associates with a decrease of the tumor antioxidant defenses (Figure 3).(33)
    Stress signals are known to regulate the metastatic growth of melanoma.(180, 181) In particular, glucocorticoids are used at high doses in cancer therapy because they have proapoptotic properties in different cancer cells.(182) Nevertheless, at the pathophysiological levels measured in plasma of tumor-bearing models, glucocorticoids show tumor-promoting activities.(180, 183) The later result may yet prove to be an undefined resistant phenotype where glucocorticoids thereby facilitate rapid growth and metastasis of various solid tumors.(182) To help unravel this paradox, we recently showed that glucocorticoid receptor knockdown decreases the Nrf2- and p53-dependent antioxidant protection of highly metastatic B16–F10 melanoma cells, thus causing a dramatic decrease (90%) in their survival upon interaction with endothelial cells both in vitro and in vivo.(180)
    It is also possible that polyphenols exert different effects depending on their concentrations. At low concentrations, they may induce Nrf2-dependent signaling and antioxidant defenses, whereas at higher concentrations they may decrease the antioxidant defenses through indirect mechanisms (such as the glucocorticoid/stress signaling mechanism mentioned above).
    Interestingly, polyphenols have been shown to affect production of steroid hormones. Daidzein, genistein, apigenin, hesperetin, naringenin, and eriodictyol (0–30 μM) significantly reduced deoxycorticosterone and androstenedione generation by cultured (24 h) human adrenocortical NCI-H295R cells.(184) Polyphenols may also influence neuroregulatory factors, neural signaling pathways, and/or the feedback mechanisms that modulate, e.g., food intake (i.e., leptin, insulin, or ghrelin).(185) Some of them, e.g., leptin, have clear tumor-promoting effects.(186)
    Another important issue involves phytoestrogens, xenoestrogens (from plants) that are not endogenously generated but introduced by consumption of phytoestrogenic plants.(187) Phytoestrogens are generally characterized as a large group of substituted natural phenolic compounds. Among phytoestrogens the coumestans, prenylflavonoids, and isoflavones elicit the strongest estrogenic effects. Most reports center on isoflavones, which are commonly found in soy and red clover. Lignans have also been identified as phytoestrogens, although they are not flavonoids. Phytoestrogens elicit effects via direct binding to estrogen receptors.(187) However, genistein is a partial androgen agonist/antagonist in some but not in all mouse tissues and must be considered as a tissue-specific androgen receptor regulator.(188)
    A 2010 meta-analysis of 15 placebo-controlled studies failed to detect any correlation of soy consumption or isoflavone supplementation to bioavailable testosterone concentrations in men. Overall, the literature suggests that phytoestrogen consumption is associated with a decreased risk of prostate cancer, especially genistein and daidzein intake (the phytoestrogens in soybeans).(189) On the other hand, it is unclear if phytoestrogens have any similar effect in female cancers. Some epidemiological studies report a protective effect against breast cancer.(190) However, recent in vitro experiments concluded that females who have had a breast cancer diagnosis may be at risk of tumor growth by consuming soy products because phytoestrogens can stimulate the growth of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer cells in vitro.(191) Nevertheless, there are deep impediments in reconciling epidemiological and experimental data because experimental doses, both in vivo and in vitro, far exceed the circulating concentrations of free unbound phytoestrogens measured in women on a high phytoestrogen diet or those taking phytoestrogen supplements. However, it is also a fact that low levels of genistein and daidzein showed the potential to stimulate tumors.(192, 193) Genistein has also been shown to either stimulate(194) or inhibit(195) the hypothalamo–pituitary–adrenal axis in adult rats. Therefore, there are controversial (possibly dose-dependent) links between stress (see above) and phytoestrogen-induced effects on specific cancer cells.
    Another potential mechanism is the possible interaction with receptors (not necessarily in the cancer cells) capable of inducing cell signaling. For instance, EGCG can be found in the cytosolic compartment and also bound to the plasma membrane, thus suggesting that this polyphenol directly interacts with membrane components.(196) In fact, it has been shown that a variety of polyphenols as well as derivatives of resveratrol competed with specific [3H]resveratrol binding in rat brain plasma membrane homogenates with the tea catechin gallates (EGCG and epicatechin gallate) displaying the highest affinities (Ki = 25–45 nM), followed by resveratrol (Ki = 102 nM).(197) Although evidence for a cell-surface EGCG receptor in different cancer cells has been claimed,(198) the fact is that EGCG at bioavailable conditions (limited concentrations and time of exposure) does not affect tumor growth significantly (Estrela et al., unpublished data).
    Metabolic syndrome is comprised of various risk factors leading to cardiovascular morbidity and mortality [visceral adiposity, elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting plasma glucose, high serum triglycerides, low high-density lipoprotein levels, hyperinsulinemia, hyperglycemia, insulin-like growth factor (IGF-I) pathway, estrogen signaling, and inflammation]. Moreover the metabolic syndrome and several types of cancer have been recently linked. Although the metabolic syndrome may not constitute a direct cause of cancer, it is associated with poorer clinical outcomes including increased risk of recurrence and overall mortality due to cancer.(199) It is also an excellent example linking altered metabolism, growth factors levels, and cancer. This is another area where polyphenols have been proposed to have potential beneficial effects.(98) Again, this exemplifies an indirect interaction between polyphenols and the cancer cells.
    Another potential mechanism entails the generation and shedding of extracellular vesicles (EVs), including exosomes and microvesicles (MVs), by cells as a form of intercellular communication with important roles in diseases such as cancer.(200) These membrane-enclosed packets can transfer specific proteins, RNA transcripts, microRNAs, and even DNA to target cells, thereby altering their function. The dynamic role of cancer cell-secreted exosomes in promoting tumorigenesis, disease progression, metastasis, angiogenesis, extracellular matrix remodeling, immune evasion, chemoresistance, and the establishment of the premetastatic niche is well documented.(200) Recently, EGCG suppression of tumor growth in a murine breast cancer model was correlated with decreased tumor-associated macrophages (TAM) and M2 macrophage infiltration. Expression of chemokine for monocytes (CSF-1 and CCL-2) was low in tumor cells from EGCG-treated mice, and cytokines of TAM were skewed from M2- into M1-like phenotype by EGCG as evidenced by decreased IL-6 and TGF-β and increased TNF-α.(201) This study concluded that exosomes derived from EGCG-treated breast cancer cells suppress tumor growth via inhibition of TAM infiltration and M2 polarization.(201) This suggests that, at in vivo achievable concentrations, EGCG may influence the communication between cancer cells and TAM. Recent evidence suggests that other polyphenols may also interfere with cancer-cell derived exosomes.(202)
    Finally, possible interactions between polyphenols and high affinity receptors must be also taken into consideration. In this sense, there is evidence of, e.g., high affinity (sub-μM range) binding of EGCG to the T-cell receptor CD4 (a T cell glycoprotein expressed on the cell surface that is integral in the antigen recognition and subsequent T cells activation),(203) flavylium flavonoids as precursors of potent ligands to brain γ-aminobutyric acid-A receptors (which negatively regulate proliferation of pluripotent and neural stem cells in embryonic and adult tissue),(204) interaction of EGCG with the ligand-binding domain of the androgen receptor through substitution of a high-affinity labeled ligand (IC50, 0.4 μM) and, in addition, of a significant down-regulation of androgen-regulated miRNA-21 and up-regulation of a tumor suppressor, miRNA-330, in tumors of mice treated with EGCG,(205) and a role of quercetin, resveratrol, and curcumin as indirect activators of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (which is known to regulate xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes including cytochrome P450).(206)
    Genistein has been also shown to have a 20-fold higher binding affinity to estrogen receptor β than estrogen receptor α.(207) Genistein also is 130-fold more potent than its counterpart 17β-estradiol to bind to estrogen receptor α.(207, 208) It has been also shown that CNS cannabinoid receptors may be targeted by selected tea catechins (EGCG Ki = 33.6 μM), but signaling via peripheral type receptors is not as likely to be important in vivo.(209) This is of particular interest because cannabinoids have the ability to activate an ER-stress related pathway that leads to the activation of autophagy-mediated cancer cell death and to inhibition of tumor angiogenesis and cancer cell migration.(210)
    However, if polyphenol-induced modulation of this intercellular trafficking/communication is truly relevant, under in vivo conditions, will depend on whether a rational correlation between bioavailability and bioefficacy can be established.

    Structural Modifications, Pharmaceutical Formulations, and Delivery Systems Aimed to Increase Bioavailability

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Polyphenols, if not limited by their low bioavailability, could directly inhibit carcinogenesis and tumor growth as well as induce tumor cell death. Unless polyphenols (at therapeutic concentrations) can directly reach a preneoplastic tissue or a growing cancer (essentially limited to the topical administration for skin tumors and to oral administration in case of gastrointestinal tract tumors), they are channeled through the bloodstream where they are subjected to rapid metabolization. Hydrophilic metabolites are re-exported to the intestinal lumen by enterocyte ABC transporters and/or rapidly excreted via the faeces and urine.(18, 133) Low water solubility and photostability are potential additional limitations.(16) Thus, methods to improve polyphenol absorption, pharmacokinetics, and efficacy are key in order to deliver therapeutic concentrations at specific target sites.
    Different companies (e.g., NanoSphere Health LLC) believe going small is the answer. Their disruptive technology focused on producing natural nanosized nutraceuticals could revolutionize how polyphenols deliver their benefits. Different drug delivery systems and pharmaceutical formulations have emerged as viable alternatives to solubilize, stabilize, or increase polyphenol bioavailability, including pro-drug design, formulation with cyclodextrin, simple emulsions, self-emulsifying delivery systems, gels, lipid nanoparticles (NPs), nanoemulsions, polymeric implantable devices, liposomes, or exosomes.(211) Nevertheless they must be stable, nontoxic, nonthrombogenic, nonimmunogeneic, noninflammatory, and biodegradable.(211) Below, we will comment only on those that appear, in our opinion, better suited for oncotherapy applications.
    Structural modifications of natural compounds, such as functional rearrangements, substitution reactions, and polymeric conjugations, have been evaluated.(212) Useful structural modifications can also be natural, as is the case for resveratrol (trans-3,5,4′-trihydroxystilbene) and its natural analogue pterostilbene (3,5-dimethoxy-4′-hydroxystilbene). Pterostilbene (with its natural dimethoxyl modifications) is about 60–100 times stronger than resveratrol as an antifungal agent, has a longer half-life, and also shows antitumor properties.(213) As a basic strategy, prodrugs offer a mechanism to deliver increased circulating blood levels of nonmetabolized natural compounds. For instance, aza-stilbenoids and their hydroxylated derivatives as 3,4,4′,5′-tetrahydroxy-trans-aza-stilbene also showed a more enhanced antiproliferative activity than resveratrol.(214) Other pro-drugs reported include the introduction of a peracetate protection to the reactive hydroxyl group in the EGCG molecule, which increases the bioavailability, stability, and proteasome inhibitory and antitumor activities of EGCG in human breast cancer cells and tumors (incubation with cell extracts converts EGCG peracetate into EGCG).(215) EGCG monoesters modified with butanoyl, octanoyl, and palmitoyl groups were also synthesized via a lipase-catalyzed transesterification method, and their antitumor activities were also studied in vitro and in vivo. Palmitoyl-modified EGCG suppressed tumor growth in vivo in colorectal tumor-bearing mice as compared to controls, vector control (DMSO), and EGCG (Matsumura 2008). Prodrugs of fluoro-substituted benzoates of EGCG have been shown to inhibit the tumor cell proteasome and to induce apoptosis in human leukemia Jurkat T cells.(216) Another study disclosed that 3-O-(3,4,5-trimethoxybenzoyl)-(−)-epicatechin showed significant antiproliferative activity against different cancer cell lines, particularly melanoma.(217) A number of quercetin and resveratrol prodrugs also have been described and assayed with limited affects (i.e., carboxyesters, sulfonates, sulfates, phosphates, acetals, carbamates, and carbonates).(218) Oligoethylene glycol chains would seem to be a strong candidate for the optimization of solubility and diffusive absorption. The possibility of exploiting membrane carriers and the behavior of possible lipophilic derivatives are two areas of investigation needing further attention.(218) Synthesis of phosphorylated salts, thus increasing polarity, is an easy option to increase water solubility and facilitate a rapid increase of different polyphenols in biological fluids.
    Emulsion–diffusion–evaporation methodologies have been extensively investigated. Solubilizing the drug and/or polymer in an organic solvent and subsequently added into an aqueous phase that contains a suitable stabilizer results into an emulsion. The emulsion can then be homogenized and diluted in water so that solvent diffusion can result in nanoprecipitation. This method provides uniformly sized spherical NPs of curcumin (120–240 nm).(219) Using oral administration, curcumin NPs can increase this polyphenol bioavailability up to approximately 25-fold as compared to a regular curcumin suspension.(219) Anionic polymerization–solvent–evaporation, multilayered polyionic/polymeric shells encapsulating NPs, solid lipid nanoparticles, or conjugation of NPs or drugs with ligands like folic acid that can recognize some cell surface markers of target cells are also viable alternative methodologies.(220)
    Following oral administration colloidal NPs are absorbed intact via lympho-epithelial M cells of Peyer’s lymphoid nodules. These particles bind to the apical side (toward the lumen) of M cells, are internalized, and then shuttled to lymphocytes.(221) The blood vessels of cancerous tumors are leaky and poorly organized. The physiologic upper limit of pore size in the blood–tumor barrier is approximately 12 nm (although pore size can reach 400–800 nm), whereas in normal vessels pores range between 2 and 4 nm.(222) This frequently very high difference may facilitate the passive targeting of tumor and inflamed tissues by NPs, leading to their accumulation and retention. Recently, a new colloidal nanogel carrier for encapsulation of curcumin showed that this formulation was 70%–85% more effective in inhibiting growth, at concentrations lower than IC50 of free curcumin, in MDA-231 breast cancer cells.(223)
    Hu et al.(224) studied the efficacy of a polymeric nanoparticle formulation of curcumin combined with sorafenib. They showed that this polymeric nanoparticle with curcumin drastically suppressed primary tumor growth and lung metastases in vivo using an orthotopic model of human hepatocellular carcinoma.
    Another example involving curcumin is the novel curcumin-loaded magnetic nanoparticle formulation that suppressed pancreatic tumor growth of HPAF-II cell line in a xenograft mouse model and significantly improved their survival.(225)
    Liposomes are spherical bilayer vesicles with an aqueous interior formed by the combination of amphiphilic phospholipids and cholesterol molecules. The effectiveness of encapsulating polyphenols into liposomes is strongly polyphenol-dependent but can result in sufficient liposomal stability. The number of rings and hydroxyl groups dictate the polyphenol solubility in surfactants.(226) Nevertheless, in specific cases such as curcumin, in vivo evidence suggests that liposomal curcumin significantly outperforms free curcumin at equimolar concentrations, emphasizing that liposomal delivery of curcumin can enhance their uptake and hence bioavailability/activity into the cells.(227) Other examples of polyphenol-encased liposomes used in biological studies can be found in ref 226.
    Implantable drug delivery systems provide a new means to achieve therapeutic drug concentrations during entire treatments in order to optimize drug action.(228) There are two types of implantable drug delivery systems: reservoir type and matrix type.(228)
    Alzet pumps (ALZA/Durect Corp., Cupertino, CA) have been the gold standard in implantable, controlled-release drug delivery for animal research (i.e., mice and rats) since their introduction in 1977 for a wide range of experimental agents, including polyphenols (e.g., resveratrol, quercetin, genistein, or curcumin).(229) These pumps operate on the basis of osmotic principles, utilizing the osmotic gradient generated after subcutaneous implantation. Alternative pumps for clinical use have been developed. Moreover, microreservoirs, passive diffusion-based reservoir devices, or actively driven reservoir devices are also potential technologies for polyphenol delivery.(228)
    Matrix type implants, which homogeneously entrap drugs in a polymeric matrix, are designed to administer sustained localized delivery into systemic circulation by slowly releasing the encapsulated drug.(228) Polymer-specific degradation dictates surface erosion type (degrade only at the surface) or bulk erosion type.(230) Polymeric implant delivery systems can provide high local concentrations of specific polyphenols (e.g., curcumin or green tea polyphenols) and also facilitate their systemic delivery.(231) However, although subcutaneous polymeric implants of curcumin, green tea polyphenols, or punicalagins showed significant inhibition of DNA adducts in rats treated with the carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene, no adduct inhibition occurred when these polyphenols were administered orally despite 10–100-fold higher doses.(231) This is another prime example of bioavailbility being the limiting factor in the bioefficacy of polyphenols.
    Exosomes, secreted by practically all mammalian cell types, are membrane-bound, intercellular communication shuttles which are defined by their endocytic origin and size range of 30–140 nm.(232) The use of exosomes as drug delivery devices is gaining in popularity. They are excellent vehicles due to their biocompatibility, stability in blood circulation, and even ability to target them to certain cell and tissue types.(232) Curcumin containing exosomes exhibit enhanced anti-inflammatory activity compared to curcumin alone.(233) The selective packaging of miR-21 in exosomes may contribute to the antileukemic effect of curcumin in chronic myelogenous leukemia.(234) Exosomes derived from EGCG-treated breast cancer cells suppress tumor growth by inhibiting TAM infiltration and M2 polarization.(201) In a recent and interesting report, Mungala et al. isolated cow milk exosomes (which exhibit cross-species tolerance with no adverse immune or inflammatory responses) and loaded them with a variety of compounds including curcumin, withaferin A, anthocyanidins, paclitaxel, and docetaxel.(235) They showed the versatility of milk exosomes with respect to the cargo it can carry and ability to reach tumor targetability. An oral exosomal–anthocyanidins formulation also showed significantly enhanced antitumor activity against lung and ovarian tumor xenograft in nude mice compared with anthocyanidins alone.(236) This is the first report to identify a biocompatible and cost-effective means of exosomes to enhance oral bioavailability and improve efficacy and safety of drugs.
    Finally, high efficiency targeted delivery systems for anticancer drugs based on tea polyphenol functionalized and reduced graphene oxide have been developed. The obtained tea PFs–graphene demonstrated an efficient doxorubicin loading capacity, exhibited pH-triggered release, showed biocompatibility to normal cells even at high concentrations, and promoted tumor cells death by delivering the doxorubicin mainly to the nuclei.(237)

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cancer is not one disease but many diseases that severely affect the human population. Thus, there is a constant demand for new therapeutic preventive treatments. Polyphenols show clear anticarcinogenic activities and also represent a potential (and effective) adjuvant/sensitizing therapy which may improve the results of different oncotherapies.
    Antitumor effects elicited by polyphenols and correlation with their bioavailability remain unclear. On the basis of current evidence, it is hard to imagine that polyphenols, at the normal exposure from food products, may have a significant anticancer activity. Polyphenols have a potent anticancer potential, but their therapeutic use must reach conditions where bioefficacy and bioavailability can be correlated. In other words, these compounds should only be examined under physiologically achievable conditions. Thus, in vivo metabolism-related limitations must be seriously taken into account in order to select the route of administration and the formulation.
    Overall, the field has been inevitably moving toward in vivo models as translation of the observed antitumor effects of polyphenols are sought to be harnessed for human health. As this Perspective shows, great strides have been made in understanding the in vivo mechanisms of action of various polyphenols. No doubt polyphenols can cause numerous antitumor effects. Nevertheless, the assumption that polyphenol-induced anticancer effects derive from the direct interaction of these natural molecules (or their metabolites) with the tumor cells frequently ignores the limitations involving in vivo concentrations and time of exposure. This Perspective questions this paradigm and invites the scientific community to consider alternative options where bioefficacy against cancer cells should also take into consideration potential relationships among in vivo metabolic rates, bioavailability, physiological neuro-endocrine mechanisms, and other mechanisms of systemic intercellular/interorgan communication.
    We can conclude that (a) polyphenols show in vitro and in vivo antitumor activities, (b) their rapid in vivo metabolism (mainly at the liver and the gastrointestinal tract) and elimination limit their bioefficacy, (c) natural chemical structures are more bioactive than their metabolites, (d) their IV administration (which avoids the gastrointestinal metabolism) presents advantages over the oral intake, although oral administration could work in the treatment of primary tumors of the gastrointestinal tract where polyphenols can directly reach the tumors, (e) improvement of pharmaceutical formulations and delivery systems to increase bioavailability (an obvious need) are being developed (i.e., water-soluble prodrugs, nanoparticles, polymeric implantable devices, liposomes, exosomes, etc.), (f) polyphenols have chemo- and radiosensitizing effects which make them suitable as adjuvants in oncotherapy, (g) their very low systemic toxicity is a clear advantage in order to combine these molecules with conventional/targeted anticancer treatments and (h) combination of two or more polyphenols may show synergic/additive effects.
    This ever-deepening understanding, coupled with methods of increasing the bioavailability of polyphenols, must allow researchers to eventually unlock the full promise of this tantalizing class of molecules.

      3
      Medicinal plants: their use in anticancer treatment
      Greenwell, M.; Rahman, P. K. S. M.
      International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research (2015), 6 (10), 4103-4112CODEN: IJPSTT; ISSN:0975-8232. (International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research)
      Globally cancer is a disease which severely effects the human population. There is a const. demand for new therapies to treat and prevent this life-threatening disease. Scientific and research interest is drawing its attention towards naturally-derived compds. as they are considered to have less toxic side effects compared to current treatments such as chemotherapy. The Plant Kingdom produces naturally occurring secondary metabolites which are being investigated for their anticancer activities leading to the development of new clin. drugs. With the success of these compds. that have been developed into staple drugs for cancer treatment new technologies are emerging to develop the area further. New technologies include nanoparticles for nano-medicines which aim to enhance anticancer activities of plant-derived drugs by controlling the release of the compd. and investigating new methods for administration. This review discusses the demand for naturally-derived compds. from medicinal plants and their properties which make them targets for potential anticancer treatments.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xls1yhtLY%253D&md5=25addd813353a17e0af04f2a762ffa87

      Hosseini, A.; Ghorbani, A. Cancer Therapy with Phytochemicals: Evidence from Clinical Studies Avicenna J. Phytomed. 2015, 5 (2) 84– 97 DOI: 10.22038/ajp.2015.3872
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Cancer therapy with phytochemicals: evidence from clinical studies
      Hosseini Azar; Ghorbani Ahmad
      Avicenna journal of phytomedicine (2015), 5 (2), 84-97 ISSN:2228-7930.
      Cancer is still one of the major causes of mortality in both developing and developed countries. At present, in spite of intensive interventions, a large number of patients suffer from poor prognosis. Therefore, the effort for finding new anticancer agents with better efficacy and lesser side effects has been continued. According to the traditional recommendations and experimental studies, numerous medicinal plants have been reported to have anticancer effect. Also antiproliferative, pro-apoptotic, anti-metastatic and anti-angiogenic effects of several phytochemicals have been shown in in vitro experiments or animal studies. However, only a small number have been tested in cancerous patients and limited evidence exists for their clinical effectiveness. Also, regarding some phytochemicals, only beneficial effects on cancer-related symptoms or on quality of life have been reported and no positive results exist for their antitumor actions. This review was focused on the phytochemicals whole beneficial effects on various types of cancer have been supported by clinical trials. Based on the literature review, curcumin, green tea, resveratrol and Viscum album were the satisfactory instances of clinical evidence for supporting their anticancer effects. The main findings of these phytochemicals were also summarized and discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2Mfhs1Gmtw%253D%253D&md5=013d1bf3b621cb633adc25906703d64e
    5. 5
      Key, T. J. Fruit and Vegetables and Cancer Risk Br. J. Cancer 2011, 104 (1) 6– 11 DOI: 10.1038/sj.bjc.6606032
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Fruit and vegetables and cancer risk
      Key T J
      British journal of cancer (2011), 104 (1), 6-11 ISSN:.
      The possibility that fruit and vegetables may help to reduce the risk of cancer has been studied for over 30 years, but no protective effects have been firmly established. For cancers of the upper gastrointestinal tract, epidemiological studies have generally observed that people with a relatively high intake of fruit and vegetables have a moderately reduced risk, but these observations must be interpreted cautiously because of potential confounding by smoking and alcohol. For lung cancer, recent large prospective analyses with detailed adjustment for smoking have not shown a convincing association between fruit and vegetable intake and reduced risk. For other common cancers, including colorectal, breast and prostate cancer, epidemiological studies suggest little or no association between total fruit and vegetable consumption and risk. It is still possible that there are benefits to be identified: there could be benefits in populations with low average intakes of fruit and vegetables, such that those eating moderate amounts have a lower cancer risk than those eating very low amounts, and there could also be effects of particular nutrients in certain fruits and vegetables, as fruit and vegetables have very varied composition. Nutritional principles indicate that healthy diets should include at least moderate amounts of fruit and vegetables, but the available data suggest that general increases in fruit and vegetable intake would not have much effect on cancer rates, at least in well-nourished populations. Current advice in relation to diet and cancer should include the recommendation to consume adequate amounts of fruit and vegetables, but should put most emphasis on the well-established adverse effects of obesity and high alcohol intakes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M%252FovVGgsQ%253D%253D&md5=05319dabbd113d4a0d31044db9a45a51

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Natural polyphenols in cancer therapy
      Asensi, Miguel; Ortega, Angel; Mena, Salvador; Feddi, Fatima; Estrela, Jose M.
      Critical Reviews in Clinical Laboratory Sciences (2011), 48 (5-6), 197-216CODEN: CRCLBH; ISSN:1040-8363. (Informa Healthcare)
      A review. Natural polyphenols are secondary metabolites of plants involved in defense against different types of stress. Exts. contg. these compds. have been used for thousands of years in traditional eastern medicine. Polyphenols act on multiple targets in pathways and mechanisms related to carcinogenesis, tumor cell proliferation and death, inflammation, metastatic spread, angiogenesis, or drug and radiation resistance. Nevertheless, reported effects claimed for polyphenols are controversial, since correlations between in vitro effects and in vivo evidence are poorly established. The main discrepancy between health claims vs. clin. observations is the frequent use of nonphysiol. relevant concns. of these compds. and their metabolites in efficacy and mechanistic studies. The present review will discuss how in vivo administration correlates with polyphenol metab., toxicity, and bioavailability. Anal. of the general application of polyphenols in cancer therapy will be complemented by potential applications in the therapy of specific tumors, including melanoma, colorectal and lung cancers. Possible pharmaceutical formulations, structural modifications, combinations, and delivery systems aimed to increase bioavailability and/or biol. effects will be discussed. Final remarks will include recommendations for future research and developments.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1KrsbbI&md5=18ac1d48ddc50804337a8b60553b7171
    8. 8
      Colomer, R.; Sarrats, A.; Lupu, R.; Puig, T. Natural Polyphenols and Their Synthetic Analogs as Emerging Anticancer Agents Curr. Drug Targets 2017, 18 (2) 147– 159 DOI: 10.2174/1389450117666160112113930
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Natural Polyphenols and their Synthetic Analogs as Emerging Anticancer Agents
      Colomer, Ramon; Sarrats, Ariadna; Lupu, Ruth; Puig, Teresa
      Current Drug Targets (2017), 18 (2), 147-159CODEN: CDTUAU; ISSN:1389-4501. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      Polyphenols are a structural class of natural and synthetic org. chems. which contain phenol units. Numerous epidemiol., preclin. and clin. studies have strongly supported their benefical effects for human health. Polyphenols group include mols. of utterly different complexity grades, ranging from simple mols. to highly polymd. structures. They are classified into: Phenolic acids, Flavonoids, Lignans and the less common Stilbenes. This work first intends to review the current studies on classification, chem. compn. and metab. of polyphenols. Then, we have reported cancer preventive and treatment effects of polyphenols, esp. focused in the green tea polyphenol (GTP) (-)-Epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG). Polyphenols such as EGCG and their synthetic analogs interfere in carcinogenesis by modulating and regulating multiple signaling pathways and transcription factors, membrane-assocd. receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs), fatty acid metab. and lipid rafts or methylation together with other emerging targets such as proteasome, telomerase and cancer stem cells. Here, we have reviewed several potential mol. targets of polyphenols (mainly EGCG and EGCG analogs) and their anticancer effects in cellular and animal models of different human carcinomas and we have also listed Phases I and II clin. trials conducted to study the antitumor properties of GTPs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1eqsrc%253D&md5=2a71804a9bb77b55b724792993951f25
    9. 9
      ClinicalTrials.gov; U.S. National Institutes of Health: Bethesda, MD, 2017; https://clinicaltrials.gov/ (accessed Jul 28, 2016).
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    10. 10
      Wang, J.; Tang, L.; Wang, J.-S. Biomarkers of Dietary Polyphenols in Cancer Studies: Current Evidence and Beyond Oxid. Med. Cell. Longevity 2015, 2015, 732302 DOI: 10.1155/2015/732302
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Biomarkers of Dietary Polyphenols in Cancer Studies: Current Evidence and Beyond
      Wang Jincheng; Tang Lili; Wang Jia-Sheng
      Oxidative medicine and cellular longevity (2015), 2015 (), 732302 ISSN:.
      Polyphenols, commonly contained in fruits and vegetables, have long been associated with a protective role against multiple diseases and adverse health effects. Generally, in vitro and animal experiments have provided strong positive evidence, whereas evidence from in vivo and human epidemiological studies is not strong enough. Most epidemiological studies to date use food frequency questionnaire based dietary intake estimations, which inevitably incur imprecision. Biomarkers of polyphenol have the potential to complement and enhance current studies. This review performed a literature search of all epidemiological studies or controlled clinical/intervention trials which employed biomarkers of exposure for polyphenols to help assess their anticarcinogenic role, using studies on green tea polyphenols as a study model. Currently, studies on this topic are still limited; breast cancer and prostate cancer were the only widely studied cancer types. Isoflavone is the only widely studied polyphenol. In addition to associations between polyphenols and cancer risks, factors such as host genetic susceptibility, epigenetic modification, and gut microbiome patterns may also impact on the protective roles of polyphenols. More evidence should be collected by utilizing biomarkers of exposure for polyphenols in future epidemiological studies before a clear conclusion can be made.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC28%252Fks1ymuw%253D%253D&md5=cc40782ac709202571417dd324189742
    11. 11
      Maru, G. B.; Hudlikar, R. R.; Kumar, G.; Gandhi, K.; Mahimkar, M. B. Understanding the Molecular Mechanisms of Cancer Prevention by Dietary Phytochemicals: From Experimental Models to Clinical Trials World J. Biol. Chem. 2016, 7 (1) 88– 99 DOI: 10.4331/wjbc.v7.i1.88
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Understanding the molecular mechanisms of cancer prevention by dietary phytochemicals: From experimental models to clinical trials
      Maru Girish B; Hudlikar Rasika R; Kumar Gaurav; Gandhi Khushboo; Mahimkar Manoj B
      World journal of biological chemistry (2016), 7 (1), 88-99 ISSN:1949-8454.
      Chemoprevention is one of the cancer prevention approaches wherein natural/synthetic agent(s) are prescribed with the aim to delay or disrupt multiple pathways and processes involved at multiple steps, i.e., initiation, promotion, and progression of cancer. Amongst environmental chemopreventive compounds, diet/beverage-derived components are under evaluation, because of their long history of exposure to humans, high tolerability, low toxicity, and reported biological activities. This compilation briefly covers and compares the available evidence on chemopreventive efficacy and probable mechanism of chemoprevention by selected dietary phytochemicals (capsaicin, curcumin, diallyl sulphide, genistein, green/black tea polyphenols, indoles, lycopene, phenethyl isocyanate, resveratrol, retinoids and tocopherols) in experimental systems and clinical trials. All the dietary phytochemicals covered in this review have demonstrated chemopreventive efficacy against spontaneous or carcinogen-induced experimental tumors and/or associated biomarkers and processes in rodents at several organ sites. The observed anti-initiating, anti-promoting and anti-progression activity of dietary phytochemicals in carcinogen-induced experimental models involve phytochemical-mediated redox changes, modulation of enzymes and signaling kinases resulting to effects on multiple genes and cell signaling pathways. Results from clinical trials using these compounds have not shown them to be chemopreventive. This may be due to our: (1) inability to reproduce the exposure conditions, i.e., levels, complexity, other host and lifestyle factors; and (2) lack of understanding about the mechanisms of action and agent-mediated toxicity in several organs and physiological processes in the host. Current research efforts in addressing the issues of exposure conditions, bioavailability, toxicity and the mode of action of dietary phytochemicals may help address the reason for observed mismatch that may ultimately lead to identification of new chemopreventive agents for protection against broad spectrum of exposures.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC28fgslynsQ%253D%253D&md5=1324eb21420d0fad4451c6d30b4e91df
    12. 12
      Boyapati, S. M.; Shu, X.; Ruan, Z. X.; Dai, Q.; Cai, Q.; Gao, Y.; Zheng, W. Soyfood Intake and Breast Cancer Survival: A Followup of the Shanghai Breast Cancer Study Breast Cancer Res. Treat. 2005, 92 (1) 11– 17 DOI: 10.1007/s10549-004-6019-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Soyfood intake and breast cancer survival: a followup of the Shanghai Breast Cancer Study
      Boyapati Sonia M; Shu Xiao-ou; Ruan Zhi Xian; Dai Qi; Cai Qiuyin; Gao Yu-tang; Zheng Wei
      Breast cancer research and treatment (2005), 92 (1), 11-7 ISSN:0167-6806.
      Soy and its constituents have been shown in many in vivo and in vitro studies and in some epidemiological studies to have anti-cancer effects. Some soy constituents, however, also stimulate cell proliferation, which has raised concerns in promoting soy intake among breast cancer survivors. To investigate whether soy intake may be associated with breast cancer survival, we evaluated data from a cohort of 1459 breast cancer patients who participated in the Shanghai Breast Cancer Study between 1996 and 1998. Usual soy food intake was assessed using a validated food frequency questionnaire at baseline. The median follow-up time for this cohort of women was 5.2 years. We found that soy intake prior to cancer diagnosis was unrelated to disease-free breast cancer survival (adjusted hazard ratio [HR]=0.99, 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.73-1.33 for the highest tertile compared to the lowest tertile). The association between soy protein intake and breast cancer survival did not differ according to ER/PR status, tumor stage, age at diagnosis, body mass index (BMI), waist to hip ratio (WHR), or menopausal status. Additionally, the soy-survival association did not appear to vary according to XbaI or PvuII polymorphisms in ER-alpha, or C(14206)T, G(25652)A, or A(50766)G polymorphisms in ER-beta. These data suggest that soyfoods do not have an adverse effect on breast cancer survival.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2MzivVWqtA%253D%253D&md5=abc9e3b60e3552635b153472adb5ce81
    13. 13
      Swann, R.; Perkins, K. A.; Velentzis, L. S.; Ciria, C.; Dutton, S. J.; Mulligan, A. A.; Woodside, J. V.; Cantwell, M. M.; Leathem, A. J.; Robertson, C. E.; Dwek, M. V. The DietCompLyf Study: A Prospective Cohort Study of Breast Cancer Survival and Phytoestrogen Consumption Maturitas 2013, 75 (3) 232– 240 DOI: 10.1016/j.maturitas.2013.03.018
